benchmark_details.name: BEND (Benchmark for DNA Language Models)
benchmark_details.overview: BEND is a Benchmark for DNA Language Models, featuring a collection of realistic and biologically meaningful downstream tasks defined on the human genome, aimed at providing a standardized set of tasks that measure the ability of LMs to capture the intricacies of genomic data.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To provide a standardized benchmark to evaluate the effectiveness of different DNA language models in capturing genomic features relevant for downstream biological tasks.

data.source: Data comes from multiple publicly available genomic datasets including GENCODE, ENCODE, GRASP, ClinVar, and the 1000 Genomes Project.
data.annotation: Annotations are made based on various genomic experiments and public datasets.

metrics: Area Under Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve (AUROC)
methodology.calculation: Metrics are calculated based on standard evaluation procedures for classification tasks.
methodology.interpretation: Higher values indicate better performance in capturing genomic features relevant to the tasks.
methodology.baseline_results: Comparative results included for existing state-of-the-art methods like AUGUSTUS and Enformer.
methodology.validation: The collected tasks and their evaluations are based on established methodologies in bioinformatics, including comprehensive testing across various models.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: Analysis of performance across different population groups included due to potential biases in the underlying genomic data.
harm: Misleading predictions that may affect genomic research and clinical applications

ethical_and_legal_considerations.data_licensing: The datasets used are governed by their respective licenses as mentioned in the paper, including usage restrictions where applicable.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.consent_procedures: The study does not require new data collection and thus does not entail new consent processes.
